title: Understanding Context Clues
task: You do not understand a joke. Select two or more clarification phrases you could say to keep the conversation friendly.
responseHint: Pick phrases you would actually use.
choices: I don't get it. Can you explain?
Wait, I didn't understand that part.
Could you explain the joke to me?

title: Showing You Understand
task: When someone tells a joke, which responses show you are listening or understand? Select all that fit.
responseHint: Choose the responses that sound natural in conversation.

title: Polite vs. Direct Speech
task: Select the more polite ways to ask a stranger for water.
responseHint: Pick the options that sound polite to a stranger.
choices: Could I have some water, please?
I would like some water, please.

title: Words with Two Meanings
task: Pick one word with two meanings and write a simple example. Use this format: Word: ___; Meaning 1: ___; Meaning 2: ___; Sentence: ___.
responseHint: Use the exact format shown in the task.
exampleAnswer: Word: bank; Meaning 1: money place; Meaning 2: river side; Sentence: I sat on the bank near the bank.

title: Formal or Friendly?
task: Write three short apologies, one for each person. Format: Boss: ___ Teacher: ___ Friend: ___. Use one short sentence each.
responseHint: Keep each line short and clear.
exampleAnswer: Boss: I sincerely apologize for being late. Teacher: I'm sorry I missed class. Friend: My bad!

title: Reading Between the Lines
task: Your friend says "I'm a bit busy right now" when you ask to hang out. Choose the best implied meaning.
choices: They cannot hang out right now.
They never want to hang out again.
They are only stating a fact with no other meaning.

title: Polite Interruptions
task: In a meeting with your teacher, which interruption is most appropriate?
choices: Excuse me, may I add something?

title: Compliment Responses
task: Write two responses to "Nice shirt!" Format: English: ___ My culture: ___.
responseHint: One for English, one for your culture.
exampleAnswer: English: Thanks! My culture: Oh, it's old, but thank you.

title: Direct vs. Indirect Requests
task: Rank by politeness: "Open the window" / "Can you open the window?" / "Could you open the window?" / "It's hot in here" / "Would you mind opening the window?" Then write: Most polite: ___ Least polite: ___ Reason: ___.
responseHint: 1 sentence for the reason is enough.
exampleAnswer: Most polite: Would you mind opening the window? Least polite: Open the window. Reason: the polite one softens the request.

title: Recognizing Sarcasm
task: Statement: "Oh great, it's raining again" (flat tone). Write two sentences: (1) the real meaning, (2) one clue that shows sarcasm.
responseHint: Keep each sentence short.
exampleAnswer: Meaning: The speaker is annoyed about the rain. Clue: the flat tone conflicts with the word great.

title: Giving Advice Politely
task: Your friend has bad breath. Options: "Your breath stinks!" / "Have you tried mints?" / "Would you like some gum?" Choose the most polite option, then write a gentle suggestion to a friend. Format: Best option: ___ Your suggestion: ___.
responseHint: Your suggestion should sound kind.
exampleAnswer: Best option: Would you like some gum? Your suggestion: You might try mints before class.

title: Refusal Without Offense
task: Write 3 lines: (1) Reason, (2) Alternative, (3) Appreciation. Keep each line short.
responseHint: Use the numbered format: 1) Reason 2) Alternative 3) Appreciation.
exampleAnswer: 1) I already have a family commitment. 2) I can help on Monday instead. 3) Thanks for understanding.

title: Email Register
task: Fix this email to your professor: "hey can u extend the deadline lol". Rewrite it with greeting, reason, polite request, thanks, and closing. Aim for 4-6 sentences.
responseHint: Include all five parts listed in the task.
exampleAnswer: Dear Professor [Name], I hope you are well. I am writing because I had a medical appointment and could not finish the essay. Could I please have a two-day extension? Thank you for your time. Sincerely, [Your Name].

title: Building Solidarity
task: List two ways close friends speak differently than acquaintances and give one example each. Format: Feature: Example.
responseHint: Keep each example to one short sentence.
exampleAnswer: Teasing: You are late again, as usual. Shared slang: That movie was so mid.

title: Disagreeing Politely
task: Use one of these starters: "I see your point, but..." / "That's interesting, however..." / "Have you considered...?" / "I respectfully disagree because..." Write a one-sentence disagreement for a class discussion.
responseHint: Use one of the starters in your sentence.
exampleAnswer: I see your point, but I think the data suggests a different conclusion.

title: Cross-Cultural Misunderstanding
task: Choose two examples (A-D) and explain why misunderstanding happens in 1-2 sentences each. A) American jokes about boss, B) Uzbek indirect refusals, C) German directness, D) Japanese vagueness.
responseHint: Label your answers with A/B/C/D.
exampleAnswer: A: In some cultures, joking about a boss sounds disrespectful. C: Directness can sound rude to listeners who expect softening.

title: Understanding Implicature
task: Friend says "Nice weather!" during a rainstorm. Write: Maxim: ___ (Quality, Quantity, Relation, Manner); Implied meaning: ___.
responseHint: Use the exact labels from the task.
exampleAnswer: Maxim: Quality. Implied meaning: The weather is bad and they are being ironic.

title: Humor Appropriateness
task: Choose one situation (funeral, job interview, or with your boss). Write two short rules: Do ___ and Don't ___.
responseHint: Keep each rule to one short sentence.
exampleAnswer: Do: keep humor mild and respectful. Don't: make jokes about death at a funeral.

title: Pragmatic Failure Analysis
task: Collect 3 real examples of pragmatic failure. For each, write: Situation, Type (pragmalinguistic or sociopragmatic), and a Fix.
responseHint: Use the format: 1) Situation - Type - Fix.
exampleAnswer: 1) Student says 'Give me water' to professor - sociopragmatic - change to 'Could I have some water, please?'.

title: Politeness Across Cultures
task: Write one request in English, your L1, and one other language. Then add two notes about directness or politeness.
responseHint: Label each language clearly.
exampleAnswer: English: Could I borrow your notes? L1: [your sentence]. Other: [your sentence]. Notes: English uses modals; L1 is more direct.

title: Creating Pragmatic Humor
task: Write three mini-dialogues (2 lines each). Label them: (1) Maxim violation, (2) Pragmatic failure, (3) Cultural script.
responseHint: Keep each dialogue to two short lines.
exampleAnswer: 1) Maxim violation: A: Is it hot? B: Antarctica is tropical today. 2) Pragmatic failure: A: Hi professor. B: Yo! 3) Cultural script: A: You must eat more. B: No, no, thank you.

title: Power and Politeness
task: Make the same request (borrow money) to: close friend, distant acquaintance, your boss, your younger sibling. Label each strategy (bald, positive, negative, off-record).
responseHint: Format: Person - Request - Strategy.
exampleAnswer: Boss - I was wondering if I could possibly borrow $20 - negative. Friend - Can you spot me $20? - positive.

title: Discourse Markers in Humor
task: Pick one joke and write it twice: with discourse markers and without them. Then explain the difference in 2 sentences.
responseHint: Keep each version short.
exampleAnswer: With: Well, I tried cooking, but anyway it was a disaster. Without: I tried cooking. It was a disaster. Difference: the markers signal a casual shift and soften the punchline.

title: Understatement Translation Challenge
description: Convert direct statements to British understatement
task: Rewrite any two statements as British understatement: 1) "This is terrible!" 2) "I completely disagree" 3) "That was an amazing performance!" 4) "I'm very angry".
responseHint: Keep each rewrite to one sentence.
exampleAnswer: 1) This is a bit of a problem. 2) I am not entirely convinced.

title: Sarcasm or Sincere?
task: Read each line with its context. Write S (sarcastic) or C (sincere): 1) "Great job" (said after a mistake), 2) "Lovely weather" (said during heavy rain), 3) "Not bad" (after an excellent presentation), 4) "Thanks a lot" (after someone interrupts you), 5) "That was brilliant" (after a funny joke), 6) "Well, that went well" (after a plan fails).
responseLabel: Write S or C for each item
responseHint: Use the exact format 1) S, 2) C, etc.

title: Hospitality Script Comparison
task: Write two short dialogues (4 lines each): one Uzbek-style and one British-style. Format: Host: ___ Guest: ___ (repeat 2 turns).
responseHint: Label each dialogue Uzbek/British.
exampleAnswer: Uzbek: Host: Have more, please. Guest: No, no, I'm full. Host: Please, just a bit more. Guest: Thank you, just a little. British: Host: Would you like some more? Guest: I'm fine, thanks. Host: Are you sure? Guest: Yes, really, thank you.

title: Self-Deprecation Response Practice
description: Learn to respond appropriately to British self-deprecation
task: For each self-deprecating statement, write an appropriate response: 1) "I'm absolutely hopeless at maths" 2) "My dancing is a danger to public safety" 3) "I have the fashion sense of a confused penguin". Write one short response each.
responseHint: Do not agree or solve the problem; just be supportive.
exampleAnswer: 1) You're being too hard on yourself. 2) I thought it was great, actually. 3) You have your own style.

title: Decode the British Feedback
task: Your British manager says these things. Write the likely meaning: 1) "That's a very brave proposal" 2) "With respect, I wonder if..." 3) "I'm sure you did your best" 4) "This is certainly ambitious" 5) "That's one way to look at it".
responseHint: Keep each meaning to one short sentence.
exampleAnswer: 1) This idea may be risky or weak. 2) I disagree politely. 3) The result was not strong. 4) It is ambitious but may be unrealistic. 5) I do not agree with that view.

title: Cultural Bridge Role-Play
task: Write one line for each step in the dinner visit: 1) accept/decline food, 2) give a compliment, 3) respond to self-deprecating humor, 4) end the evening politely.
responseHint: Use the numbered format from the task.
exampleAnswer: 1) Thank you, just a small portion. 2) The food smells wonderful. 3) It was delicious, you did great. 4) Thank you for having me, I had a lovely time.

title: Explain Uzbek Humour to a British Person
task: Choose an Uzbek joke or humour tradition and explain it. Use this structure: (1) Short summary, (2) Why it is funny, (3) Cultural knowledge needed, (4) One similarity or difference with British humour.
responseHint: Label each part 1-4.
exampleAnswer: 1) Summary: In an askiya exchange, one person answers with clever wordplay. 2) Funny because the reply flips the meaning. 3) You need to know the cultural expectation of witty replies. 4) Similar to British banter but more ritualized.

title: Watch and Analyze British Comedy
task: After watching a short clip, list: (1) three understatements, (2) two sarcasm lines, (3) one self-deprecating moment. Use labels.
responseHint: Use labels: Understatement 1-3, Sarcasm 1-2, Self-deprecation 1.
exampleAnswer: Understatement 1: Not bad. Understatement 2: Could be worse. Understatement 3: A bit tricky. Sarcasm 1: Lovely weather. Sarcasm 2: Great job. Self-deprecation 1: I'm hopeless at this.

title: Askiya Payrov Recognition
description: Learn to identify the four main askiya formats
task:
Askiya has different formats called 'payrov' (themes). Learn these four types:

• OKHSHATDIM (Comparison): 'I compare you to X because Y'
• QOFIYA (Rhyme): Keep the rhyme pattern going or lose
• LAQAB (Nickname): Give a clever nickname with explanation
• BOLASIZMI (Trap): Yes/no questions where both answers lead to teasing

Now identify which payrov type (A, B, C, or D) each example uses:

A = Okhshatdim | B = Qofiya | C = Laqab | D = Bolasizmi

1) 'Sizni eshakka o'xshatdim!' - 'Nega?' - 'Og'ir yuk ko'tarasiz, lekin tez yurmaysiz!'
(I compare you to a donkey - you carry heavy loads but move slowly!)

2) 'Yoshmisiz?' - 'Ha' - 'Unda nega qariyalar kabi shikoyat qilasiz?'
(Are you young? - Yes - Then why do you complain like old people?)

3) 'Laqabingiz Kalit!' - 'Nega?' - 'Har eshikni ochasiz - lekin hech birida qolmaysiz!'
(Your nickname is Key! - You open every door but stay in none!)

4) 'Bog'da gul, Tog'da bul...' - opponent must continue with rhyme
(Flower in garden, Spring on mountain... - continue the -ul rhyme)

Write your answers: 1-?, 2-?, 3-?, 4-?
responseHint: Look for the structure: comparison uses 'o'xshatdim', trap uses yes/no question, nickname uses 'laqab', rhyme needs continuing
exampleAnswer: 1-A (Okhshatdim - comparison to donkey), 2-D (Bolasizmi - yes/no trap about age), 3-C (Laqab - nickname Key), 4-B (Qofiya - rhyme pattern -ul)

title: Askiya Response Practice
task:
In Okhshatdim askiya, when someone compares you to something, you must respond with your own clever comparison. The key rule: be 'subtle, light and kind' - never mean or hurtful.

Here is a challenge you received:

Opponent: 'Sizni oyga o'xshatdim!' (I compare you to the moon!)
You: 'Nega?' (Why?)
Opponent: 'Chunki faqat kechasi chiqasiz - kunduzi uxlaysiz!'
(Because you only come out at night - you sleep all day!)

Now create YOUR response. Follow this structure:

1) Choose something to compare your opponent to (object, animal, thing)
2) Make sure it sounds positive at first
3) Add a witty twist that gently teases

Example good response:
'I compare YOU to a calendar! Why? Because everyone looks at you... but only to see when the holiday comes!'

Write your own comparison with the 'Why?' and explanation.
responseLabel: Write: I compare you to [X]! Why? Because [witty explanation]
responseHint: Good objects to use: mirror, dictionary, clock, umbrella, WiFi - things that seem useful but have a funny limitation
exampleAnswer: I compare you to a dictionary! Why? Because you have all the words but nobody wants to read you for fun!

title: Askiya vs British Banter: Cross-Cultural Analysis
description: Compare how Uzbek and British cultures use humor to tease
task:
Both Uzbek askiya and British banter allow people to tease each other playfully. But they work differently. Read both examples carefully:

UZBEK ASKIYA (Okhshatdim format):
A: 'Sizni kitobga o'xshatdim!' (I compare you to a book!)
B: 'Nega?' (Why?)
A: 'Muqovangiz chiroyli, lekin ichingizni hech kim o'qimaydi!'
(Your cover is beautiful, but nobody reads what's inside!)

BRITISH BANTER (Understatement + sarcasm):
A: 'Nice presentation, mate.'
B: 'Cheers!'
A: 'No really, I almost stayed awake.'

Both examples criticize someone (saying they're superficial / saying the presentation was boring). But the METHOD is different.

Answer these four questions (2-3 sentences each):

1) DELIVERY: How does each culture wrap the criticism? (Uzbek uses _____, British uses _____)

2) TIMING: In askiya, must you respond immediately? In British banter, is there a pause?

3) SKILL: Which style requires faster thinking? Why?

4) TRANSLATION: If you translated askiya directly to English, would it work? If you used British sarcasm in Uzbekistan, would people understand?
responseLabel: Answer all four questions with examples
responseHint: Key differences: metaphor vs understatement, immediate vs delayed response, elaborate vs deadpan
exampleAnswer: 1) DELIVERY: Uzbek wraps criticism in elaborate metaphor (book = beautiful outside, empty inside). British uses understatement then reversal (nice... almost stayed awake). 2) TIMING: Askiya requires immediate counter-response. British banter allows pauses for deadpan effect. 3) SKILL: Askiya needs faster thinking because you must create a new metaphor instantly. British relies on timing more than speed. 4) TRANSLATION: Direct askiya translation sounds too elaborate in English. British sarcasm without tone markers might seem rude in Uzbek - people may take 'nice presentation' literally.

title: Create Your Own Askiya Dialogue
description: Write a complete askiya exchange on a modern topic
task:
Create your own askiya dialogue using the OKHSHATDIM (comparison) format. Choose ONE modern topic: Technology, University Life, or Social Media.

Follow this exact structure:

A: 'I compare you to [something]!'
B: 'Why?'
A: '[Witty explanation with gentle tease]'
B: 'Well, I compare YOU to [something else]!'
A: 'Why?'
B: '[Counter-explanation that is equally clever]'

REMEMBER THE GOLDEN RULE: Askiya must be 'subtle, light and kind' - never cruel or humiliating.

Here is an example on the topic TECHNOLOGY:

A: 'I compare you to my old laptop!'
B: 'Why?'
A: 'You take 10 minutes to start working in the morning!'
B: 'Well, I compare YOU to a smartphone battery!'
A: 'Why?'
B: 'You start the day at 100% energy but by 2pm you are completely dead!'

Now write YOUR dialogue (4-6 lines). State your topic first.
responseLabel: Write: Topic: [your choice], then your 4-6 line dialogue
responseHint: Good comparisons for University: library book, exam paper, lecture hall. For Social Media: notification, profile picture, hashtag
exampleAnswer: Topic: University Life. A: I compare you to a library book! B: Why? A: Everyone needs you before exams, but the rest of the year you sit alone on the shelf! B: Well, I compare YOU to the university WiFi! A: Why? B: Everyone depends on you, but you disconnect exactly when people need you most!

title: Askiya and Pragmatic Theory
description: Understand why askiya rules match linguistic politeness theory
task:
Askiya has traditional rules that performers must follow. These rules actually match what linguists call 'pragmatic principles' - the hidden rules of polite communication.

Read each ASKIYA RULE, then match it to the correct PRAGMATIC CONCEPT:

PRAGMATIC CONCEPTS (choose from these):
• Face Theory (Brown & Levinson) - protecting people's self-image and dignity
• Grice's Relevance Maxim - staying on topic, being relevant
• Grice's Manner Maxim - being clear and responding appropriately
• Politeness Strategies - softening criticism to avoid offense

ASKIYA RULES:

1) 'Mockery should be subtle, light and kind'
This means: Don't be harsh, wrap criticism in gentle humor
Which concept? _____

2) 'Never damage the honor and dignity of a rival'
This means: Protect your opponent's reputation even while teasing
Which concept? _____

3) 'Each response must relate to the theme (payrov)'
This means: If the topic is 'flowers', don't suddenly talk about 'cars'
Which concept? _____

4) 'Quick, relevant responses are valued'
This means: Answer promptly and clearly, don't ramble
Which concept? _____

Write your answers: 1-[concept], 2-[concept], 3-[concept], 4-[concept]
pragmaticFocus: Connecting cultural practice to linguistic theory
responseLabel: Match each rule (1-4) to a pragmatic concept
responseHint: Think: Rule 1 and 2 are about being KIND (politeness/face). Rules 3 and 4 are about being CLEAR and ON-TOPIC (Grice).
exampleAnswer: 1-Politeness Strategies (softening criticism), 2-Face Theory (protecting dignity), 3-Grice's Relevance Maxim (staying on topic), 4-Grice's Manner Maxim (being clear and prompt)
